publicwhip.spmotion: *S2M-5599 Mike Pringle: Success for the University of Edinburgh—That the Parliament congratulates Edinburgh Parallel Computing Centre at the University of Edinburgh for its success in having been selected to house, manage and direct the latest £113 million national high performance computing facility for UK computational science, HECToR (High End Computing Terascale Resource), which will provide UK researchers with a world-class capability to undertake increasingly complex studies across a range of scientific disciplines.

S2M-5599 Mike Pringle: Success for the University of Edinburgh—That the Parliament congratulates Edinburgh Parallel Computing Centre at the University of Edinburgh for its success in having been selected to house, manage and direct the latest £113 million national high performance computing facility for UK computational science, HECToR (High End Computing Terascale Resource), which will provide UK researchers with a world-class capability to undertake increasingly complex studies across a range of scientific disciplines. Supported by: Mark Ballard*, Stewart Stevenson*, John Swinburne*, Mr Kenny MacAskill*
S2M-5599 Success for the University of Edinburgh (lodged on 15 February 2007) Mr Jim Wallace*, Mr Jamie Stone*, Donald Gorrie*
S2M-5599 Success for the University of Edinburgh (lodged on 15 February 2007) Margaret Smith*
S2M-5599 Success for the University of Edinburgh (lodged on 15 February 2007) Dr Jean Turner*
S2M-5599 Success for the University of Edinburgh (lodged on 15 February 2007) Mr Brian Monteith*
S2M-5599 Success for the University of Edinburgh (lodged on 15 February 2007) Susan Deacon*

S2M-5599 Mike Pringle: Success for the University of Edinburgh—That the Parliament congratulates Edinburgh Parallel Computing Centre at the University of Edinburgh for its success in having been selected to house, manage and direct the latest £113 million national high performance computing facility for UK computational science, HECToR (High End Computing Terascale Resource), which will provide UK researchers with a world-class capability to undertake increasingly complex studies across a range of scientific disciplines. Supported by: Mark Ballard, Stewart Stevenson, John Swinburne, Mr Kenny MacAskill, Mr Jim Wallace, Mr Jamie Stone, Donald Gorrie, Margaret Smith, Dr Jean Turner, Mr Brian Monteith, Susan Deacon
